**Is this a BUG REPORT or FEATURE REQUEST?**:

> Uncomment only one, leave it on its own line: 
>
/kind bug
> /kind feature


**What happened**:

kube-proxy came up cleanly but mis-configured iptable rules due to a mis-match in the hostname and node name within the cluster triggering a default behavior.  In this case the hostname returned the fqdn of the host and the cluster only had the hostname.  This resulted in the following warning messages when kube-proxy started.

```
W1220 16:46:26.875651       1 server.go:580] Failed to retrieve node info: nodes "node07.example.com" not found
W1220 16:46:26.875785       1 proxier.go:471] invalid nodeIP, initializing kube-proxy with 127.0.0.1 as nodeIP
```
Which then presents itself as pods not being able to access clusterip ip addresses with no route errors.

**What you expected to happen**:

Would it be better to fail to in this scenario rather than try to fall back to some default?  I spent a good amount of time trying to track down the Error messages that were a result of this before finally working back to taking a closer at the Warning message.

**How to reproduce it (as minimally and precisely as possible)**:

Start the kube-proxy with `--hostname-override` set to an invalid hostname should recreate this issue.

**Anything else we need to know?**:

While I think we can chalk up this issue to mis-configuration the purpose of opening this issue is really to have a conversation about the default behavior.  I've seen several other issues filed that appear to be related to this behavior: #35641, #37414, #40653.

* Would throwing an error and exiting non-zero be a better default action when the nodeIP is nil?
* What use case(s) does a default of `127.0.0.1` support?
* If there must be a default behavior here maybe the IP address on the interface associated with the default gateway is a better default than `127.0.0.1`?
* Maybe the issue isn't in the proxier code but the kube-proxy itself should error when it fails to get node info rather than a warning?

**Environment**:
I'm not sure how much of this is important to this but here's what my environment was when I ran into this.
- Kubernetes version: 1.8.5
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: Bare metal
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Centos 7 and Ubuntu 16.04

title: kube-proxy's default behavior of using nodeIP 127.0.0.1 when nodeIP is nil seems problematic
